TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in GPE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was recruited by the embassy of GPE in GPE ( “ the embassy ” or “ the NORP embassy ” ) , to the post of secretary and switchboard operator ( korespondentė - telefonistė ) .

CARDINAL . The contract of employment provided in DATE that the applicant ’s responsibilities and tasks were limited by the scope of her ( secretarial and switchboard - related ) duties . If the applicant agreed , she could be assigned other tasks not covered by this agreement . In such circumstances , a new contract would have to be signed . According to LAW had to comply with NORP laws , was liable for any damage she might cause to her employer and could be subjected to disciplinary action for failing to fulfil her professional obligations or to observe safety regulations at work . In return for extra work , the applicant could receive remuneration , bonuses , discretionary benefits or compensatory leave . Article CARDINAL provided that any disputes arising under the contract were to be settled in accordance with the laws of GPE : the LAW , LAW , LAW , LAW and LAW . Lastly , the contract could be terminated in accordance with sections CARDINAL , DATE , DATE and CARDINAL of LAW ( enacted on DATE with a number of subsequent amendments ) .
CARDINAL . NORP The applicant ’s duties – as set out in a schedule to her employment contract – included the following :
“ CARDINAL . Operating the switchboard of the embassy and FAC and recording international telephone conversations .
CARDINAL . Typing texts in NORP and NORP .
CARDINAL . Operating the fax machine .
CARDINAL . Providing information in NORP , NORP and NORP .
CARDINAL . Helping to organise small receptions and cocktail parties .
CARDINAL . Photocopying documents .
CARDINAL . Performing other work at the request of the head of the mission . ”

CARDINAL . In DATE the applicant lodged a complaint before the Equal Opportunities Ombudsman , alleging sexual harassment by CARDINAL of her male colleagues , a member of the diplomatic staff of the embassy . Following an inquiry , the ORG reported that the applicant was indeed a victim of sexual harassment . The applicant alleged that she had fallen ill because of the tension she was experiencing at work .

CARDINAL . The applicant was on sick leave from DATE to DATE . On DATE she went to work but was not authorised to enter the embassy building . On DATE the applicant was again refused entry when she arrived for work . The same thing occurred again on DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant wrote a letter to the ambassador , informing her about the incidents . On DATE the applicant was notified that she had been dismissed on the ground of her failure to come to work from CARDINAL to CARDINAL DATE .

CARDINAL . The applicant brought a civil claim , requesting compensation for unlawful dismissal . She did not claim reinstatement . The NORP Minister for ORG issued a note verbale claiming immunity from the jurisdiction of the NORP courts . On DATE ORG discontinued the proceedings for lack of jurisdiction . On DATE ORG upheld the decision . The final decision was taken by ORG on DATE .

CARDINAL . ORG established , inter alia , that the DATE agreement on legal assistance between GPE and GPE had not resolved the question of ORG immunity , that GPE had no laws on the question , and that the domestic case - law in this area was only just being developed . ORG therefore considered it appropriate to decide the case in the light of the general principles of international law , in particular the DATE LAW .

CARDINAL . ORG observed that LAW , as then in force , established the principle of absolute State immunity , but that that provision had become inapplicable in practice . It noted that the prevailing international practice was to adopt a restrictive interpretation of ORG immunity , granting such immunity only for acts of sovereign authority ( acta jure imperii ) , as opposed to acts of a commercial or private - law nature ( acta jure gestionis ) . ORG further held , in particular , as follows :

“ ... in ORG view , it is possible to apply the principle of restrictive immunity to GPE . Having regard to the fact that GPE recognises that foreign nationals may bring actions in respect of private - law disputes , it must be accepted that , in order to defend their rights , individuals or entities from GPE are entitled to take proceedings against foreign GPE .

It is thus necessary to establish in the present case whether the relationship between the claimant and GPE was CARDINAL of a public - law nature ( acta jure imperii ) or a private - law nature ( acta jure gestionis ) . Besides that , other criteria are applicable and should allow [ the court ] to determine whether the ORG concerned enjoys immunity ... in employment disputes . These criteria include , in particular , the nature of the workplace , the status of the employee , the territorial connection between the country of employment and the country of the court , and the nature of the claim .

Regard being had to the plea of immunity by ORG GPE ... it is possible to conclude that there was a public - service relationship governed by public law ( acta jure imperii ) between the claimant and the embassy of GPE , and that GPE may lay claim to immunity from the jurisdiction of foreign courts . This conclusion is supported by other criteria . With regard to the nature of the workplace , it should be noted that the main function of the embassy ... is directly related to the exercise of sovereignty of GPE . With respect to the status of [ the ] employee ... while the parties had entered into a contract of employment , the very fact that the employee was a switchboard operator implies that the parties developed a relationship akin to that which characterises a public - service function ... The court was unable to obtain any information allowing it to establish the scope of the claimant ’s actual duties . Thus , merely from the title of her position , it can be concluded that the duties entrusted to her facilitated , to a certain degree , the exercise by GPE of its sovereign functions . ... It must also be established whether the country of employment is the country of the court , since a court in the country of employment is best placed to resolve a dispute that has arisen in that country . In this respect , it is to be recognised that the exercise of the sovereign powers of the forum ORG is severely restricted with regard to an embassy , even though it is not a foreign territory as such ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of ORG ) . As to the nature of the claim ... it should be noted that a claim for recognition of unlawful dismissal and for compensation can not be regarded as violating the sovereignty of [ another ] ORG , since such a claim pertains solely to the economic aspect of the impugned legal relationship [ ; ] there is no claim for reinstatement ... However , by reason of this criterion alone , it can not be unconditionally asserted that GPE can not invoke ORG immunity in this case . ... [ The claimant ] has submitted no [ other ] evidence to confirm the inability for GPE to enjoy ORG immunity ( Article CARDINAL of the Code of Civil Procedure ) .

Against the background of the above criteria , [ in view of ] the aspiration of GPE and GPE to maintain good bilateral relations ... and respect the principle of sovereign equality between GPE ... , the chamber concludes that the courts [ below ] properly decided that they had no jurisdiction to entertain this case .

ORG notes that both ORG of GPE and ORG based the decision to apply jurisdictional immunity to GPE merely on the fact that the latter had refused to appear in the proceedings . Those courts did not examine the question of the application of restrictive jurisdictional immunity in the light of the criteria developed by ORG . However , this breach of procedural rules does not constitute , in ORG view , a ground for quashing the decisions of the courts below . ...
The application of jurisdictional immunity by the courts of GPE does not prevent the claimant from taking proceedings before the NORP courts . ”

CARDINAL . There is no special legislation governing the issue of ORG immunity in GPE . The question is usually resolved by the courts on a case - by - case basis , with reference to the provisions of various bilateral and multilateral treaties .
CARDINAL . LAW ( applicable at the material time and in force until DATE ) established the rule of absolute State immunity :

“ Adjudication of actions against foreign GPE , and adoption of measures of constraint and execution against the property of a foreign ORG , shall be allowed only with the consent of the competent institutions of the foreign ORG . ”

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG gave a decision in the case of PERSON v. GPE embassy , regarding an action for unlawful dismissal against GPE embassy in GPE . LAW was considered by the court to be inappropriate in the light of the changing reality of international relations and public international law . ORG noted the trend in international legal opinion to restrict the categories of cases in which a foreign ORG could invoke immunity from the jurisdiction of forum courts . It held that NORP legal practice should follow the doctrine of restrictive ORG immunity . It found , inter alia , as follows :

“ State immunity does not mean immunity from institution of civil proceedings , but immunity from jurisdiction of courts . The LAW establishes the right to apply to a court ( LAW ... However , the ability of a court to defend the rights of a claimant , where the defendant is a foreign ORG , will depend on whether that foreign ORG requests the application of the ORG immunity doctrine ... In order to determine whether or not the dispute should give rise to immunity ... it is necessary to determine the nature of the legal relations between the parties ... ”

CARDINAL . On DATE the plenary of ORG adopted a decision regarding “ Judicial Practice in GPE in Applying Rules of Private International Law ” ( PERSON , no . CARDINAL ) . It stated that while LAW established a norm whereby “ foreign GPE [ and ] diplomatic and consular representatives and diplomats of foreign NORP ] immunity from the jurisdiction of NORP courts ” , that rule guaranteed ORG immunity only for “ legal relations governed by public law ” . ORG pointed out that when deciding whether or not a case containing an international element fell within the jurisdiction of NORP courts , the court in question had to consider whether its judgment would be recognised and enforced in the foreign ORG concerned or whether it would refuse to do so . If the case also fell within the jurisdiction of a foreign court , the forum court would be entitled to relinquish jurisdiction and instruct the claimant to take proceedings in the court of the foreign ORG where the judgment should be enforced .
This interpretation by ORG had to be followed by the lower courts .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG delivered a judgment in a case that was very similar to that of the applicant , namely ORG v. the embassy of GPE . It found that “ despite the fact that GPE had not enacted any legislation on ORG immunity , it could nevertheless be seen from the case - law of the domestic courts that GPE recognised the doctrine of restrictive State immunity ” . In that case it was considered that the provisions of LAW and their Property , adopted on DATE , could be taken into account , even though they were not binding , since they reflected a certain trend in international law in matters of ORG immunity . ORG further observed that the case - law of the courts of both States – GPE and GPE – being based on common practice in international relations , confirmed that they had been adhering to a restrictive approach to ORG immunity , whereby a ORG could not claim immunity from jurisdiction if the dispute was of a private - law nature . In such cases GPE could not therefore object to the case being heard by the NORP courts . However , ORG held that the dispute between the parties had arisen from a public - law relationship and was not an employment relationship under private law .

CARDINAL . ORG further observed that there was no uniform international practice of GPE whereby the members of staff of foreign States’ diplomatic missions who participated in the exercise of the public authority of the GPE they represented could be distinguished from other members of staff . As there were no legally binding international rules , it was for each ORG to take its own decisions in such matters .
CARDINAL . The relevant provisions of the DATE LAW ( “ the Basle Convention ” ) read as follows :

“ CARDINAL . A Contracting State can not claim immunity from the jurisdiction of a court of ORG if the proceedings relate to a contract of employment between the ORG and an individual where the work has to be performed on the territory of the ORG of the forum .
CARDINAL . Paragraph CARDINAL shall not apply where :
( a ) the individual is a national of the employing ORG at the time when the proceedings are brought ;
( b ) at the time when the contract was entered into the individual was neither a national of the State of the forum nor habitually resident in that ORG ; or

( c ) the parties to the contract have otherwise agreed in writing , unless , in accordance with the law of the State of the forum , the courts of that ORG have exclusive jurisdiction by reason of the subject matter . ... ”

CARDINAL . The Convention ’s Explanatory Report indicates that “ [ GPE regards contracts of employment with diplomatic missions or consular posts , Article CARDINAL shall also be taken into account ” . That Article provides as follows :
“ Nothing in the present Convention shall affect privileges and immunities relating to the exercise of the functions of diplomatic missions and consular posts and of persons connected with them . ”
CARDINAL . Neither GPE nor GPE are parties to LAW .

CARDINAL . In DATE ORG ( ILC ) was given the task of codifying and gradually developing international law in matters of jurisdictional immunities of GPE and their property . It produced a number of drafts that were submitted to GPE for comment . GPE never made any negative observation on those drafts . ORG that were used as the basis for the text adopted in DATE dated back to DATE . The relevant part of the text then read as follows :

“ CARDINAL . Unless otherwise agreed between the GPE concerned , a ORG can not invoke immunity from jurisdiction before a court of another ORG which is otherwise competent in a proceeding which relates to a contract of employment between the ORG and an individual for work performed or to be performed , in whole or in part , in the territory of that other ORG .
CARDINAL . Paragraph CARDINAL does not apply if :
( a ) the employee has been recruited to perform functions closely related to the exercise of governmental authority ;
( b ) the subject of the proceeding is the recruitment , renewal of employment or reinstatement of an individual ;
( c ) the employee was neither a national nor a habitual resident of the State of the forum at the time when the contract of employment was concluded ;
( d ) the employee is a national of the employer ORG at the time when the proceeding is instituted ; or

( e ) NORP the employer ORG and the employee have otherwise agreed in writing , subject to any considerations of public policy conferring on the courts of the ORG of the forum exclusive jurisdiction by reason of the subject matter of the proceeding . ”

CARDINAL . In the commentary on the ORG ’s ORG of DATE , it was stated that the rules formulated in LAW appeared to be consistent with the trend in the legislative and treaty practice of a growing number of States ( ILC Yearbook , DATE , PERSON . II , Part CARDINAL , p. CARDINAL , paragraph CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . NORP In DATE ORG adopted LAW and their Property . It was opened for signature on DATE . CARDINAL of the major issues that had arisen during the codification work by the ORG related to the exception from ORG immunity in so far as it related to employment contracts . The final version of LAW , as set out in the Convention , reads as follows :

“ CARDINAL . Unless otherwise agreed between the GPE concerned , a ORG can not invoke immunity from jurisdiction before a court of another ORG which is otherwise competent in a proceeding which relates to a contract of employment between the ORG and an individual for work performed or to be performed , in whole or in part , in the territory of that other ORG .
CARDINAL . Paragraph CARDINAL does not apply if :
( a ) the employee has been recruited to perform particular functions in the exercise of governmental authority ;
( b ) the employee is :
( i ) a diplomatic agent , as defined in LAW ;
( ii ) a consular officer , as defined in LAW of DATE ;
( iii ) a member of the diplomatic staff of a permanent mission to an international organisation or of a special mission , or is recruited to represent a ORG at an international conference ; or
( iv ) any other person enjoying diplomatic immunity ;
( c ) the subject matter of the proceeding is the recruitment , renewal of employment or reinstatement of an individual ;

( d ) the subject matter of the proceeding is the dismissal or termination of employment of an individual and , as determined by the head of ORG , the head of government or the Minister for ORG of the employer State , such a proceeding would interfere with the security interests of that State ;
( e ) the employee is a national of the employer ORG at the time when the proceeding is instituted , unless this person has the permanent residence in the ORG of the forum ; or

( f ) the employer ORG and the employee have otherwise agreed in writing , subject to any considerations of public policy conferring on the courts of the ORG of the forum exclusive jurisdiction by reason of the subject matter of the proceeding . ”
CARDINAL . DATE GPE did not vote against the adoption of this text but has not ratified it either .
